member.name: T:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo
member.summary:
This class organizes constants and routines for working with arrays. The constants are mostly synonyms for constants that exist in other classes and assemblies.
Since static classes are implicitly sealed, this class cannot be inherited.
member.remarks: For ease of access, I promoted the classes that expose only constants to the root of the WizardWrx namespace.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT
member.summary: Since array subscripts start at zero, the first element of any array is zero. Since the same holds for most things that go into square brackets or are called some kind of index, this constant works as well with indexes.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ARRAY_IS_EMPTY
member.summary: The Length and LongLength properties of an array return zero (ARRAY_IS_EMPTY) when the array is empty.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ARRAY_INVALID_INDEX
member.summary: It follows from the fact that array indices count from zero that anything less is invalid.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ARRAY_NEXT_INDEX
member.summary: The next index is plus one, which is ambiguous, at best, in code.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ARRAY_SECOND_ELEMENT
member.summary: There is an amazing number of situations that require a refeerence to the second element of an array or list.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.INDEX_FROM_ORDINAL
member.summary: If ORDINAL_FROM_INDEX is +1, then its inverse should be -1. Thus, both operations are additions, which are typically a tad faster, since they don't have to manage a Carry flag.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.MSO_COLLECTION_FIRST_ITEM
member.summary: Indexing of collections of Microsoft Office objects begins at plus one.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.NEXT_INDEX
member.summary: The next index is plus one, which is ambiguous, at best, in code. listings.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.ORDINAL_FROM_INDEX
member.summary: This grain of syntactic sugar is used in OrdinalFromIndex and made visible as documentation and for coding similar math inline when space permits.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.IndexFromOrdinal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Given an ordinal, such as an array element count, return the equivalent index (subscript) value.
member.param: Specify the ordinal to convert.
member.returns: The return value is the index equivalent to pintIndex.
member.remarks: Mathematically, the index is pintOrdinal - ORDINAL_FROM_INDEX. Hence, this routine is syntactic sugar, which a good optimizer will optimize away by generating the code inline.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.OrdinalFromIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Given an index, such as an array subscript, return the equivalent ordinal value.
member.param: Specify the index to convert.
member.returns: The return value is the ordinal equivalent to pintIndex.
member.remarks: Mathematically, the ordinal is pintIndex + ORDINAL_FROM_INDEX. Hence, this routine is syntactic sugar, which a good optimizer will optimize away by generating the code inline.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ArrayInfo.RemoveAt``1(``0[],System.Int32)
member.summary: This method removes the element at index (subscript) from array .
member.typeparam: The type parameter is unconstrained, since the relevant concern is that the input is an array.
member.param: Specify the array from which the element at subscript should be removed.
Specify the zero-based index (subscript) of the element to be removed from array .
member.returns: The return value is a new array of type T from which the element at subscript has been removed.

remarks.para: This method is implemented as an extension method.

As mentioned by the article cited herein, since arrays are immutable objects, the only way to plysically remove an element from it is by creating a new array and copying into it every element except the one to be excluded.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark
member.summary: Use this class to evaluate arbitrary byte arrays for the presence of a Byte Order Mark.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType
member.summary: Members of this enumeration report the type of byte order mark, if any, present at its beginning.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.None
member.summary: The array has no Byte Order Mark.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF8
member.summary: The array has a UTF-8 Byte Order Mark.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF16LE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-16 Byte Order Mark that indicates little-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: The little-endian encoding is the native encoding of the entire Intel processor family and its clones (e. g., AMD).

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF16BE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-16 Byte Order Mark that indicates big-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: The big-endian encoding is the native encoding of the MIPS Alpha family of processors, among others.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UnicodeLittleEndian
member.summary: UnicodeLittleEndian is a synonym of UTF16LE, the encoding that corresponds to the wide character encoding on Microsoft Windows.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UnicodeBigEndian
member.summary: UnicodeLittleEndian is a synonym of UTF16BE, the encoding that corresponds to the wide character encoding on Microsoft Windows, running on a big-endian processor, which MAY include code that runs on ARM processors.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF32LE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-32 Byte Order Mark that indicates little-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: This seldom-used encoding is defined for completeness, and in anticipation of its usage increasing.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF32BE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-32 Byte Order Mark that indicates big-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: This seldom-used encoding is defined for completeness, and in anticipation of its usage increasing.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: The only public constructor demands a reference to the byte array to evaluate.
member.param: Supply a reference to the byte array to test for a Byte Order Mark.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.Kind
member.summary: This read-only property returns the type of Byte Order Mark present in the byte array that was supplied to the constructor.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.Length
member.summary: This read-only property returns the length of the Byte Order Mark.
member.remarks: Since the property is initialized on first use, it may display an invalid value of -1 in a watch window.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.TestForBOM
member.summary: If it hasn't been directly called, the first call to either property getter calls this method, so that the work required to evaluate the array for a byte order mark is deferred until it is needed, and it is never subsequently repeated for the lifetime of the instance.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo
member.summary: Use these constants and service routines to simplify working with CSV type files.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo.EMPTY_FILE
member.summary: The Length property of a file returns this value to indicate that a file is absolutely empty.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo.FIRST_RECORD
member.summary: When you use Syatem.IO.File.ReadAllLines to read an entire file into an array of strings, this constant refers to the first data row of a labeled CSV file.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo.LABEL_ROW
member.summary: When you use Syatem.IO.File.ReadAllLines to read an entire file into an array of strings, this constant refers to the label row of a labeled CSV file.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo.RecordCount(System.String[])
member.summary: Derive the record count from the length of an array of records loaded from a labeled CSV type file.
member.param:
Array populated with all records read from a text file
Please see the Remarks section.
member.returns:
Number of records in file, excluding the expected label row
Please see the Remarks section.
member.remarks:
This method starts from the Length property of array pastrWholeFile.
For the most part, this function is syntactic sugar. Given an array, pastrWholeFile, populated with strings that represent every record in a text file, this function returns the record count, adjusted for the label row that is assumed to be present.
This assumption is justified by the fact that I almost always put a label row in my delimited ASCII text files, even if the intended use doesn't require one, because it makes diagnostic studies so much easier. In the long run, I prefer to have my programs discard the unneeded label row than have a carbon unit try to figure out what is supposed to be in each of its columns.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.CSVFileInfo.LongRecordCount(System.String[])
member.summary: Derive the record count from the length of an array of records loaded from a labeled CSV type file.
member.param:
Array populated with all records read from a text file
Please see the Remarks section.
member.returns:
Number of records in file, excluding the expected label row
Please see the Remarks section.
member.remarks:
This method starts from the LongLength property of array pastrWholeFile.
For the most part, this function is syntactic sugar. Given an array, pastrWholeFile, populated with strings that represent every record in a text file, this function returns the record count, adjusted for the label row that is assumed to be present.
This assumption is justified by the fact that I almost always put a label row in my delimited ASCII text files, even if the intended use doesn't require one, because it makes diagnostic studies so much easier. In the long run, I prefer to have my programs discard the unneeded label row than have a carbon unit try to figure out what is supposed to be in each of its columns.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats
member.summary:
Pass these constants to the ToString method on an object of the appropriate type to render the object for printing.
The comment associated with each constant identifies the types for which it is appropriate.
There are service methods to facilitate using the Date/Time formatting constants, which cannot be fed to ToString, except, perhaps, with a custom formatting engine. Use these service methods, or call the ReformatSysDate function, which also belongs to this library, directly.
NOTE: The time formatting strings and routines in this class are time zone agnostic. If you want or need the time zone, use the companion method, GetDisplayTimeZone, defined in sibling class Util.

member.summary: Pass this constant to the ToString method on any integral type to format it as an arbitrary string of hexadecimal digits, using lower case glyphs..

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.INTEGER_PER_REG_SETTINGS
member.summary: Use this string to format an integer per the Regional Settings applet in the Windows Control Panel, overriding its default setting for digits after the decimal point, which is meaningless for an integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS
member.summary:
Pass this constant to the ToString method on any integral type to format it according to the current settings in the Regional Settings part of the Windows Control Panel.
This format string causes the formatting engine to obey ALL of the settings, including the number of digits to display after the decimal point for a whole number.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_0D
member.summary:
Pass this constant to the ToString method on any integral type to format it according to the current settings in the Regional Settings part of the Windows Control Panel.
This format string causes the formatting engine to obey all of the settings, EXCEPT the number of digits to display after the decimal point for a whole number.
This format string overrides the digits after decimal value specified by the iDigits value of Windows Registry key HKCU\Control Panel\International, causing it to behave as if it had been set to 0.
The override applies only to the instance ToString method being called; the Registry is unchanged.
See http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc978638.aspx.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_2D
member.summary:
Pass this constant to the ToString method on any integral type to format it according to the current settings in the Regional Settings part of the Windows Control Panel.
This format string causes the formatting engine to obey all of the settings, EXCEPT the number of digits to display after the decimal point for a whole number.
This format string overrides the digits after decimal value specified by the iDigits value of Windows Registry key HKCU\Control Panel\International, causing it to behave as if it had been set to 2, which happens to be the default for a US installation. Nevertheless, uses this value if changes made by the user would mess up your work.
The override applies only to the instance ToString method being called; the Registry is unchanged.
See http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc978638.aspx.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_3D
member.summary:
Pass this constant to the ToString method on any integral type to format it according to the current settings in the Regional Settings part of the Windows Control Panel.
This format string causes the formatting engine to obey all of the settings, EXCEPT the number of digits to display after the decimal point for a whole number.
This format string overrides the digits after decimal value specified by the iDigits value of Windows Registry key HKCU\Control Panel\International, causing it to behave as if it had been set to 3.
The override applies only to the instance ToString method being called; the Registry is unchanged.
See http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc978638.aspx.

member.summary: Pass this constant to the ToString method on a single or double precision floating point number to be displayed as an integral percentage.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DisplayFormats.PERCENT_DIGITS_2
member.summary: Pass this constant to the ToString method on a single or double precision floating point number to be displayed as a fixed point percentage, accurate to two decimal places.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags
member.summary: Use these flags to document stream I/O method calls.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE_FORBIDDEN
member.summary:
File copy and stream I/O operations on existing files must fail.
This is the default behavior, and an existing file raises an IOException exception.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE_PERMITTED
member.summary: File copy and stream I/O operations on existing files overwrite.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_READ_ENCODING_CHECK_FOR_BOM
member.summary:
When opening a text file for input, use the Byte Order Mark, if present, to establish its encoding.
The documentation in the MSDN library describes this parameter as follows.
"The detectEncodingFromByteOrderMarks parameter detects the encoding by looking at the first three bytes of the stream. It automatically recognizes UTF-8, little-endian Unicode, and big-endian Unicode text if the file starts with the appropriate byte order marks. Otherwise, the UTF8Encoding is used."
The documentation implies, without explicitly saying so, the text is assumed to be UTF-8 encoded unless you check for a Byte Order Mark, one is present, and it indicates otherwise.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_READ_ENCODING_IGNORE_BOM
member.summary:
When opening a text file for input, ignore (expect none) the Byte Order Mark to establish its encoding.
The documentation in the MSDN library describes this parameter as follows.
"The detectEncodingFromByteOrderMarks parameter detects the encoding by looking at the first three bytes of the stream. It automatically recognizes UTF-8, little-endian Unicode, and big-endian Unicode text if the file starts with the appropriate byte order marks. Otherwise, the UTF8Encoding is used."
The documentation implies, without explicitly saying so, the text is assumed to be UTF-8 encoded unless you check for a Byte Order Mark, one is present, and it indicates otherwise.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_OUT_APPEND
member.summary:
Opening an output stream on a file that exists extends the file. The file is created if it doesn't exist.
The documentation implies, without explicitly saying so, that the default is overwrite.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.FILE_OUT_CREATE
member.summary:
Opening an output stream on a file that exists overwrites the file. Otherwise, a new file is created.
The documentation implies, without explicitly saying so, that the default is overwrite.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.MAKE_STREAM_IO_ASYNCHRONOUS
member.summary: Open stream for asynchronous I/O.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.FileIOFlags.MAKE_STREAM_IO_SYNCHRONOUS
member.summary: Open stream for synchronous I/O. This is the default.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ListInfo
member.summary:
This static class exposes handy constants for working with buffers, lists, and substrings.
Since static classes are implicitly sealed, this class cannot be inherited.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.BEGINNING_OF_BUFFER
member.summary:
Use this to signify the beginning of a binary I/O buffer.
Coincidentally, this happens to be ArrayInfo.ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT, which is logical, since a buffer is an array.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.BINARY_SEARCH_NOT_FOUND
member.summary:
Since the BinarySearch method on a List returns the array subscript where the value was found, a return value of less than zero (BINARY_SEARCH_NOT_FOUND) means that no matching item exists in the list.
Coincidentally, this happens to be ArrayInfo.ARRAY_INVALID_INDEX.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.EMPTY_STRING_LENGTH
member.summary: The Length property of a string returns a value of zero (EMPTY_STRING_LENGTH) when the string is empty.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND
member.summary:
This constant defines the value returned by the IndexOf method on a string to indicate that the search character or substring is not found.
Coincidentally, this happens to be ArrayInfo.ARRAY_INVALID_INDEX.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.LIST_IS_EMPTY
member.summary: The Count property of a list returns a value of zero (LIST_IS_EMPTY) when the list is empty.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ListInfo.SUBSTR_BEGINNING
member.summary:
Since a string is an array of Unicode characters, it makes sense to treat substrings as arrays.
Coincidentally, this happens to be ArrayInfo.ARRAY_FIRST_ELEMENT, which is logical, since a substring is an array of Unicode characters.

members.member:
Since a string is an array of Unicode characters, it makes sense to treat substrings as arrays.
Coincidentally, this happens to be ArrayInfo.ARRAY_SECOND_ELEMENT, which is logical, since a substring is an array of Unicode characters.
If the function cannot return the requested character, the return value is SpecialCharacters.NUL, the null character.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ListInfo.FirstCharOfString(System.String)
member.summary: Return the first character of a string.
member.param: Specify the string from which to return the first character.
member.returns:
Unless the input string is empty (or null), the return value is its first character.
If the function cannot return the requested character, the return value is SpecialCharacters.NUL, the null character.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ListInfo.LastCharacterOfString(System.String)
member.summary: Return the last character of a string.
member.param: Specify the string from which to return the last character.
member.returns:
Unless the input string is empty (or null), the return value is its last character.
If the function cannot return the requested character, the return value is SpecialCharacters.NUL, the null character.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ListInfo.NthCharacterOfString(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the character at the Nth position in a string.
member.param: Specify the string from which to return the last character.
Specify the ordinal position of the desired character. Unlike array subscripts, which start at zero, ordinals start at one.
member.returns:
Unless the input string is empty (or null), or pintOrdinalPosition is less than 1 or greater than the length of the string, the return value is the character at the specified (Nth) position.
If the function cannot return the requested character, the return value is SpecialCharacters.NUL, the null character.

Unless the input string is empty (or null), the return value is its penultimate character.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans
member.summary:
This class defines frequently used Boolean values whose correct values are easier to remember with the help of a mnemonic.
This class is one of a constellation of static classes that define a wide variety of symbolic constants that I use to make my code easier to understand when I need a refresher or am about to change it.
member.remarks: The constants defined herein are pairs. The first part of the name of each pair associates it with the method or constructor with which it is intended to be used. The remainder of the name identifies the behavior elicited from the object or method by specifying this value.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.ENUM_PARSE_CASE_INSENSITIVE
member.summary: Use this constant as the third (ignoreCase) argument of the static Enum.Parse method to cause the evaluation to be case INsensitive.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.ENUM_PARSE_CASE_SENSITIVE
member.summary: Use this constant as the third (ignoreCase) argument of the static Enum.Parse method to cause the evaluation to be case sensitive. This is the default behavior of Enum.Parse exhibited by the two-argument overload of this method.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE_FORBIDDEN
member.summary: Use with the third argument of the static Copy method of the File class to explicitly forbid file overwriting. See Remarks.
member.remarks: If you NEVER want overwriting, use the default (two-argument) form of the Copy method.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE_PERMITTED
member.summary: Use with the third argument of the static Copy method of the File class to enable file overwriting, which is forbidden by default.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.FILE_OUT_APPEND
member.summary: Use this symbolic constant to set the append argument to an overloaded StreamWriter constructor, to cause it to append to a file if one exists.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.FILE_OUT_CREATE
member.summary: Use this symbolic constant to set the append argument to an overloaded StreamWriter constructor, to cause it to overwrite a file if one exists.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.MAKE_STREAM_IO_ASYNCHRONOUS
member.summary: Use this symbolic constant to set the useAsync argument to a FileStream constructor to TRUE, allowing I/O to be asynchronous.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.MagicBooleans.MAKE_STREAM_IO_SYNCHRONOUS
member.summary: Use this symbolic constant to set the useAsync argument to a FileStream constructor to FALSE, allowing I/O to be synchronous, which is the default.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.CURRENCY
member.summary:
Currency, which obeys the Regional Settings for currency, including the currency symbol and number of decimal places to show.
The negative sign comes from the regional settings, and leads the string, and the precision applies to the number of decimal (fraction) digits.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.DECIMAL
member.summary:
Decimal, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an exception.
If the number requires fewer than the specified minimum number of digits, it is padded on the left with zeros, and there are no thousands separators.
The negative sign comes from the regional settings, and leads the string, and the precision applies to the number of digits to the left of the implied decimal point.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.FIXED
member.summary:
This is the minimal fixed point format string. Modifiers can be appended to it to specify significant digits after the decimal point.
The negative sign comes from the regional settings, and leads the string, and the precision applies to the number of decimal (fraction) digits.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static FixedPointDecimal ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the framework.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.FIXED_2
member.summary: This gives fixed point, with 2 places to the right of the decimal point, and without thousands separators.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.FIXED_3
member.summary: This gives fixed point, with 3 places to the right of the decimal point, and without thousands separators.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.GENERAL_LC
member.summary:
This is the default, and it's pretty minimal. The documentation states that the number is converted to the most compact format.
When the size of the number and the specified precision dictate use of scientific notation, the exponential symbol is lower case; this is the only difference between this format and GENERAL_UC.
When the specified number of places after the decimal point is zero, the decimal point is omitted.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.GENERAL_UC
member.summary:
This is the default, and it's pretty minimal, as it must be, since its status as the default means that it is the only format that supports all data types (numbers, dates, times, time spans, and all the rest. It is also among the few that render output left aligned.
The documentation states that the number is converted to the most compact format.
When the size of the number and the specified precision dictate use of scientific notation, the exponential symbol is UPPER case; this is the only difference between this format and GENERAL_LC.
When the specified number of places after the decimal point is zero, the decimal point is omitted.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HEXADECIMAL_LC
member.summary:
Use this string as your argument to the ToString method of any integral data type to format it in hexadecimal notation, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an FormatException exception.
This format yields a result containing the fewest hexadecimal glyphs required to represent the number. The difference between this token and HEXADECIMAL_LC is that this token causes the returned string to contain UPPER case glyphs, while HEXADECIMAL_LC yields lower case glyphs.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HEXADECIMAL_UC
member.summary:
Use this string as your argument to the ToString method of any integral data type to format it in hexadecimal notation, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an FormatException exception.
This format yields a result containing the fewest hexadecimal glyphs required to represent the number. The difference between this token and HEXADECIMAL_LC is that this token causes the returned string to contain UPPER case glyphs, while HEXADECIMAL_LC yields lower case glyphs.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HEXADECIMAL_2
member.summary:
Use this string as your argument to the ToString method of any integral data type to format it in hexadecimal notation, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an FormatException exception.
This format yields a result containing a minimum of two hexadecimal numerals. If the number needs more than two numerals, the returned string contains the minimum number of hexadecimal numerals required to represent the integer.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.summary:
Hexadecimal, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an exception.
This format yields a result containing a minimum of four hexadecimal numerals. If the number needs more than two numerals, the returned string contains the minimum number of hexadecimal numerals required to represent the integer.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HEXADECIMAL_8
member.summary:
Hexadecimal, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an exception.
This format yields a result containing a minimum of 8 hexadecimal numerals. If the number needs more than two numerals, the returned string contains the minimum number of hexadecimal numerals required to represent the integer.
Use this format to represent result codes returned by Windows DLLs and other such functions that return things such as HRESULTs.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HEXADECIMAL_16
member.summary:
Hexadecimal, which the documentation says is supported only for integral types. They mean business; if you try to use this type with a decimal or floating point number, you get an exception.
This format yields a result containing a minimum of 16 hexadecimal numerals. If the number needs more than 16 numerals, the returned string contains the minimum number of hexadecimal numerals required to represent the integer.
Use this format to represent long integer values, such as file sizes and 64 bit masks.
To easily specify the desired minimum number of hexadecimal glyphs, along with any of the prefixes and suffixes defined in this set of HEXADECIMAL_* constants, call static method IntegerToHexStr ( [T] , int pintTotalDigits , HexFormatDecoration penmDecoration ), in lieu of calling ToString on the integer.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.INTEGER_PER_REG_SETTINGS
member.summary: Format an integer per the Regional Settings in the Windows Control Panel. Sine this string is intended exclusively for formatting an Integer, it overrides the default regional settings value for Number of Digits After Decimal. Please see the Remarks for additional details.
member.remarks: Since this string is intended exclusively for formatting an Integer, it overrides the default regional settings value, which is the value reported when GetLocaleInfo is called with its LCType argument set to LOCALE_IDIGITS (0x00000011, per WinNLS.h), which lives at HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\International[iDigits] in the Windows Registry, and corresponds to the "No. of digits after decimal" property shown on the Numbers tab displayed by the Additional Settings button on the Region and Language Windows Control Panel applet dialog box.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS
member.summary:
Format a number (any numeric type), using the Regional Settings (Locale) defaults for thousands separator, decimal symbol, number of decimal (fraction) places, and number of digits to display between each thousands separator.
Use this string as your argument to the ToString method of any numeric data type to format it in decimal notation, with zero or more places after the decimal point.
When the specified number of places after the decimal point is zero, the decimal point is omitted.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static NumberPerRegSettings ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the Base Class Library.
A shortcut to get an integer formatted is IntegerPerRegSettings.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_0D
member.summary:
Feed this string to the ToString method of any numeric value to format it according to the Regional Settings (Locale) defaults for thousands separator, decimal symbol, and number of digits to display between each thousands separator.
In contrast to NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS, this string overrides the default decimal places value, and always displays ZERO digits to the right of the decimal point.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static NumberPerRegSettings ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the Base Class Library.
A shortcut to get an integer formatted is IntegerPerRegSettings, and an alias, which avoids the overhead of a method call, is INTEGER_PER_REG_SETTINGS.
member.remarks: Since this string is intended exclusively for formatting an Integer, it overrides the default regional settings value, which is the value reported when GetLocaleInfo is called with its LCType argument set to LOCALE_IDIGITS (0x00000011, per WinNLS.h), which lives at HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\International[iDigits] in the Windows Registry, and corresponds to the "No. of digits after decimal" property shown on the Numbers tab displayed by the Additional Settings button on the Region and Language Windows Control Panel applet dialog box.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_2D
member.summary:
Feed this string to the ToString method of any numeric value to format it according to the Regional Settings (Locale) defaults for thousands separator, decimal symbol, and number of digits to display between each thousands separator.
In contrast to NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS, this string overrides the default decimal places value, and always displays two digits to the right of the decimal point.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static NumberPerRegSettings ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the Base Class Library.
A shortcut to get an integer formatted is IntegerPerRegSettings.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS_3D
member.summary:
Feed this string to the ToString method of any numeric value to format it according to the Regional Settings (Locale) defaults for thousands separator, decimal symbol, and number of digits to display between each thousands separator.
In contrast to NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS, this string overrides the default decimal places value, and always displays three digits to the right of the decimal point.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static NumberPerRegSettings ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the Base Class Library.
A shortcut to get an integer formatted is IntegerPerRegSettings.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.PERCENT
member.summary:
Display a fixed point number as a percentage, using the default number of decimal places, per the Regional Settings (Locale). The number is multiplied by 100 before the formatting is applied. Hence, 0.25 renders as 25%.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static PercentToDecimalPlaces ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the framework.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.PERCENT_DIGITS_2
member.summary:
Display a fixed point number as a percentage, showing two digits to the right of the decimal point.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static PercentToDecimalPlaces ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the framework.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.ROUND_TRIP
member.summary: Since the formatting engine ignores if for this type, there is no corresponding format string generator, and only one token, since there is no documented difference between the upper and lower case token. Before you use this token, read the documentation cited below carefully.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.SCIENTIFIC_LC
member.summary:
Scientific notation, with a lower case "e" for the exponent. Exactly one digit always precedes the decimal point.
To specify the number of places to print after the decimal point, use the static PercentToDecimalPlaces ( int pintFractionDigits ) method, which supports any number between zero and ninety-nine, the limits imposed by the framework.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.SCIENTIFIC_UC
member.summary: Scientific notation, with an upper case "E" for the exponent. Exactly one digit always precedes the decimal point.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.DECIMAL_DIGITS_DEFAULT
member.summary:
For some applications, such as the static methods of this class, we set our own default number of decimal places, rather than relying on the Regional Settings (Locale), which can be changed, at any time, by any user, even with restricted permissions.
Format String Generator Routine Width Override
DECIMAL FixedWidthInteger int pintTotalDigits
FIXED FixedPointDecimal int pintFractionDigits
GENERAL GeneralXPrecision int pintPrecisionDigits [1]
HEXADECIMAL HexadecimalInteger int pintTotalDigits
NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS IntegerPerRegSettings N /A
NUMBER_PER_REG_SETTINGS NumberPerRegSettings int pintFractionDigits
PERCENT PercentToDecimalPlaces int pintFractionDigits
Note 1: There is only one of these methods, and it accepts the pintTotalDigits argument.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.DECIMAL_DIGITS_MIN
member.summary:
The static format string generator methods in this class test the requested number of decimal points against this lower limit.
If the specified number is less than this value, the methods behave as if the default had been specified.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.DECIMAL_DIGITS_MAX
member.summary:
The static format string generator methods in this class test the requested number of decimal points against this upper limit.
If the specified number is greater than this value, the methods behave as if the default had been specified.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.DECIMAL_DIGITS_NONE
member.summary: This is a synonym of DECIMAL_DIGITS_MIN.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.FixedPointDecimal
member.summary: Return a string suitable for formatting a fixed point number.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.IntegerToHexStr``1(``0)
member.summary: Properly formatting an integral type as a hexadecimal string, including the decorations commonly applied to them as prefix or suffix, is a bit beyond the reach of a simple ToString format string.
member.typeparam: There are no compiler enforced constraints on this type, because the Base Class Library provides no mechanism to differentiate integral types in constraints for generics. See the remarks for a comment about how we get around this.
member.param: Specify the value to be formatted as hexadecimal. Integral types only, because that's the only type that may be formatted in this way.
member.returns:
The returned string consists of the prefix, immediately followed by the hexadecimal number, itself, and, finally, the suffix.
Theoretically, you can have both a prefix and a suffix, but the idea is to have one or the other, but not both. You can mix and match upper and lower case glyphs in the main number string and the decorations.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.IntegerToHexStr``1(``0,WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HexFormatDecoration)
member.summary: Properly formatting an integral type as a hexadecimal string, including the decorations commonly applied to them as prefix or suffix, is a bit beyond the reach of a simple ToString format string.
member.typeparam: There are no compiler enforced constraints on this type, because the Base Class Library provides no mechanism to differentiate integral types in constraints for generics. See the remarks for a comment about how we get around this.
member.param: Specify the value to be formatted as hexadecimal. Integral types only, because that's the only type that may be formatted in this way.
The HexFormatDecoration has the Flags attribute set on it, so that it can be processed as a bit mask, enabling it to specify multiple items.
member.returns:
The returned string consists of the prefix, immediately followed by the hexadecimal number, itself, and, finally, the suffix.
Theoretically, you can have both a prefix and a suffix, but the idea is to have one or the other, but not both. You can mix and match upper and lower case glyphs in the main number string and the decorations.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.IntegerToHexStr``1(``0,System.Int32)
member.summary: Properly formatting an integral type as a hexadecimal string, including the decorations commonly applied to them as prefix or suffix, is a bit beyond the reach of a simple ToString format string.
member.typeparam: There are no compiler enforced constraints on this type, because the Base Class Library provides no mechanism to differentiate integral types in constraints for generics. See the remarks for a comment about how we get around this.
member.param: Specify the value to be formatted as hexadecimal. Integral types only, because that's the only type that may be formatted in this way.

Specify the minimum number of hexadecimal "digits" (glyphs, really) to render. If the number needs more than the specified number, the method uses as many as it needs, causing the returned string to be longer than you expected. If the string needs fewer characters, it is left padded with zeros.
member.returns:
The returned string consists of the prefix, immediately followed by the hexadecimal number, itself, and, finally, the suffix.
Theoretically, you can have both a prefix and a suffix, but the idea is to have one or the other, but not both. You can mix and match upper and lower case glyphs in the main number string and the decorations.
member.remarks:
The available options are overloading the single-argument ToString method on all fourteen integer types, or crafting one generic method that takes the integer to format as its first argument. Since it's a lot less work, I went that route.
Although this method uses generics, there is no type constraint, because the Base Class Library offers no such constraint to filter integral types, of which there are at least fourteen, not counting BigInteger. Since the compiler won't enforce a type constraint, I wrote my own routine that enforces it at run time, by searching a table of known integral types, identified by their GUID properties. If the type of pintegralValue matches an entry in the list, the input is accepted. Otherwise, you get an ArgumentException exception that clearly explains what happened and why.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.NumericFormats.IntegerToHexStr``1(``0,System.Int32,WizardWrx.NumericFormats.HexFormatDecoration)
member.summary: Properly formatting an integral type as a hexadecimal string, including the decorations commonly applied to them as prefix or suffix, is a bit beyond the reach of a simple ToString format string.
member.typeparam: There are no compiler enforced constraints on this type, because the Base Class Library provides no mechanism to differentiate integral types in constraints for generics. See the remarks for a comment about how we get around this.
member.param: Specify the value to be formatted as hexadecimal. Integral types only, because that's the only type that may be formatted in this way.

Specify the minimum number of hexadecimal "digits" (glyphs, really) to render. If the number needs more than the specified number, the method uses as many as it needs, causing the returned string to be longer than you expected. If the string needs fewer characters, it is left padded with zeros.
The HexFormatDecoration has the Flags attribute set on it, so that it can be processed as a bit mask, enabling it to specify multiple items.
member.returns:
The returned string consists of the prefix, immediately followed by the hexadecimal number, itself, and, finally, the suffix.
Theoretically, you can have both a prefix and a suffix, but the idea is to have one or the other, but not both. You can mix and match upper and lower case glyphs in the main number string and the decorations.
member.remarks:
The available options are overloading the single-argument ToString method on all fourteen integer types, or crafting one generic method that takes the integer to format as its first argument. Since it's a lot less work, I went that route.
Although this method uses generics, there is no type constraint, because the Base Class Library offers no such constraint to filter integral types, of which there are at least fourteen, not counting BigInteger. Since the compiler won't enforce a type constraint, I wrote my own routine that enforces it at run time, by searching a table of known integral types, identified by their GUID properties. If the type of pintegralValue matches an entry in the list, the input is accepted. Otherwise, you get an ArgumentException exception that clearly explains what happened and why.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.PathPositions
member.summary:
Use these constants to document path string parsing.
Since static classes are implicitly sealed, this class cannot be inherited.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.PathPositions.FQFN_PREFIX_START_POS
member.summary: The FQFN prefix refers to the drive and path substring, ":\" which starts in the second position of the substring, preceded by the logical drive letter. In keeping with the treatment of strings and substrings as arrays, its value is an index. Accordingly, its value is equated to ArrayInfo.ARRAY_SECOND_ELEMENT.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.PathPositions.FQFN_PREFIX_START_LEN
member.summary:
The prefix of an absolute path string is TWO characters. Some very OLD programs, display little or no awareness of directories. Hence, they render only the first of the two characters (the full colon).
By this means, you can tell whether a path name is one of these 'old" path strings, or, at the very least, must be interpreted relative to the logged directory on the specified logical drive.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.PathPositions.MAX_PATH
member.summary: In theory, Windows NT supports really long file names that can run to thousands of characters. However, due to the limitations of the commonly used Windows file system APIs, the practical limit on the length of a file name string remains stuck at MAX_PATH, 260 characters.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.PathPositions.UNC_HOSTNAME_PREFIX_POS
member.summary: By their very nature, a canonical UNC path string is absolute, and it must begin with two fixed characters, "\\". In keeping with the treatment of string and substrings as arrays, its value is an index. Accordingly, its value is equated to ArrayInfo.ARRAY_SECOND_ELEMENT.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.PathPositions.UNC_HOSTNAME_START_POS
member.summary: Since a UNC path string begins with two fixed characters, it follows that the hostname, itself, begins at offset 2 (character 3). In keeping with the treatment of string and substrings as arrays, its value is an index.

member.summary: This static class exposes methods for loading text from custom resources that are embedded in an assembly.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.LoadTextFileFromCallingAssembly(System.String)
member.summary: Load the lines of a plain ASCII text file that has been stored with the assembly as a embedded resource into an array of native strings.
member.param: Specify the absolute (fully qualified) resource name, which is its source file name appended to the default assembly namespace.
member.returns: The return value is an array of Unicode strings, each of which is the text of a line from the original text file, sans terminator.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.LoadTextFileFromEntryAssembly(System.String)
member.summary: Load the lines of a plain ASCII text file that has been stored with the assembly as a embedded resource into an array of native strings.
member.param: Specify the fully qualified resource name, which is its source file name appended to the default application namespace.
member.returns: The return value is an array of Unicode strings, each of which is the text of a line from the original text file, sans terminator.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.LoadTextFileFromAnyAssembly(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Load the lines of a plain ASCII text file that has been stored with a specified assembly as a embedded resource into an array of native strings.
member.param: Specify the absolute (fully qualified) resource name, which is its source file name appended to the default assembly namespace name.
Pass in a reference to the Assembly from which you expect to load the text file. Use any means at your disposal to obtain a reference from the System.Reflection namespace.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.LoadBinaryResourceFromAnyAssembly(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Load the named embedded binary resource into a byte array.
member.param: Specify the external name of the file as it appears in the source file tree and the Solution Explorer.
Supply a System.Reflection.Assembly reference to the assembly that contains the embedded resource.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, it returns a byte array containing the raw bytes that comprise the embedded resource. Hence, this method can load ANY embedded resource.
member.remarks:
Since all other resource types ultimately come out as byte arrays, the text file loaders call upon this routine to extract their data.
The notes in the cited reference refreshed my memory of observations that I made and documented a couple of weeks ago. However, it was a lot easier to let Google find a reference document, which was intended for students in the Computer Science department at Columbia University, at http://www1.cs.columbia.edu/~lok/csharp/refdocs/System.IO/types/Stream.html"/>, than find my own source.
member.exception: An Exception (the base Exception type) arises when the method is called with a value that cannot be found in the assembly. When the exception arises during the read operation, the generic Exception wraps an InvalidDataException exception, which is returned as its InnnerException property.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.NameValueCollectionFromEmbbededList(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Construct a NameValueCollection from the tab delimited list read from a text file stored in an embedded resource.
member.param:
Specify the name of the text file as it appears in the Solution Explorer (or the Windows Explorer, for that matter).
IMPORTNAT: The file must be marked as an embedded resource; do this in the Solution Explorer by displaying the properties of the file.
The specified string is checked against the label row; unless both are identical, the resource is assumed to be corrupted, and the method throws an exception and croaks.
member.returns: If the method succeeds, it returns a NameValueCollection of key/value pairs that contains exactly one value per key.
member.exception: And ArgumentException is thrown when the data file referenced by contains duplicate keys, if one of the records contains two or more values, or the input file is empty. The messages attached to the exceptions are explicit about which of the three conditions caused the exception, and they attempt to provide enough detail to enable the programmer to quickly identify and resolve the problem.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.EmbeddedTextFileReaders.StringFromANSICharacterArray(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Transform an array of bytes, each representing one ANSI character, into a string.
member.param: Specify the array to transform.
member.returns: The array is returned as a string.
member.remarks: I did this refactoring, thinking that I had a new use for the code, only to realize as I finished cleaning it up that I can't use it, because it deals in ANSI characters, and my present need involves Unicode characters. Nevertheless, the exercise is not a total loss, because it reminded me of the trick that I needed to transform the array of Unicode characters into a string.

member.returns: Array of strings, one line per string. Blank lines are preserved as empty strings.

member.summary: Split a string containing lines of text into an array of strings, as modified by the StringSplitOptions flag.
member.param: String containing lines of text, terminated by CR/LF pairs.

A member of the StringSplitOptions enumeration, presumably other than StringSplitOptions.None, which is assumed by the first overload. The only option supported by version 2 of the Microsoft .NET CLR is RemoveEmptyEntries.
member.returns: Array of strings, one line per string. Blank lines are preserved as empty strings unless penmStringSplitOptions is RemoveEmptyEntries, as is most likely to be the case.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport
member.summary: Constants, some built from others by static methods, to expedite common tasks that use regular expressions.
member.remarks: Reference: RegExLib.com Regular Expression Cheat Sheet (.NET), at the cross reference cited below.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_ALTERNATION
member.summary:
Like the binary Logical OR operator in a logical expression, this character says "match either the character on its left OR the character on its right.
Regular expressions may contain many alternations, forming a group that behaves commutatively.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_ESCAPE
member.summary:
Preceding another meta-character, one of these tells the Engine to treat the meta character as a literal.
Preceding certain other characters, one of these signals a special, non-printing character. For example, preceding a lower case a, it signifies an Alarm (Bell). More commonly, however, before a lower case t, this character signifies a Tab, before a lower case n means a Newline, and a lower case r denotes a Carriage Return.
N. B. A Newline in the .NET RegExp Engine and in the Perl RegExp Engine are two different things.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_GROUP_BEGIN
member.summary: Define the start of a group. This is the same as a subexpression in Perl.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_GROUP_END
member.summary: Define the end of a group. This is the same as a subexpression in Perl.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_MULTIPLE_PREVIOUS_CHAR
member.summary: Match zero or more of the previous character or expression.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_ONE_OR_MORE_PREVIOUS_CHAR
member.summary: Match one or more of of the previous character or expression.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_SHORTEST
member.summary: Append to a greedy match to make it match the fewest possible characters.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_STRING_START
member.summary: Match start of line, absent the String modifier, which changes its meaning to match start of the entire String.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_STRING_END
member.summary: Match end of line, absent the String modifier, which changes its meaning to match end of the entire String.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_WILDCARD_CHAR
member.summary:
Match one of any character, except a Newline (absent the String modifier, which adds the Newline to the list of matched characters.
Use MATCH_MULTIPLE_PREVIOUS_CHAR to extend the match to a string of the same character.
Use MATCH_SHORTEST, following this character, followed by MATCH_MULTIPLE_PREVIOUS_CHAR, to limit the match.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.CARRIAGE_RETURN
member.summary: Represents a Carriage Return (CR in Windows text) in a Regular Expression

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_DTM_YYYYMMDD_FORMATTED
member.summary: Match a date in YYYY/MM/DD format, where the delimiter can be ANY character.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MATCH_DTM_HHMMSS_FORMATTED

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.ESCAPED_QUOTE

member.remarks: See "How to avoid VBScript regular expression gotchas," at http://www.xaprb.com/blog/2005/11/04/vbscript-regular-expression-gotchas/, especially the responses.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.PAGE_TAG_SUFFIX

member.summary: Title attribute of the ASP.NET Page tag looks like this.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.REGEXP_WHOLE_MATCH
member.summary: In the .NET version of the regular expression matching engine, the first group, whose index is zero, matches the whole expression.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.REGEXP_FIRST_MATCH
member.summary: Not surprisingly, the .NET regular expression returns a collection of matches. Like all collections, individual members are numbered from zero.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.REGEXP_FIRST_SUBMATCH
member.summary: In the .NET version of the regular expression matching engine, the subexpressions are numbered from 1, just as they are in Perl.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.FRIEDL_HTML_TAG_MATCH
member.summary:
Jeffrey Friedl's regular expression for matching any arbitrary HTML tag.
Jeffrey Friedl is the author of Mastering Regular Expressions, published by O'Reily, which is regarded as the "Bible" of Regular Expressions.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.MODIFIED_FRIEDL_HTML_TAG_MATCH
member.summary: This is a derivation of Jeffrey Friedl's regular expression, adapted to capture the tag name in the first submatch.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.FRIEDL_GRAY_WHOLE_HTML_TAG_MATCH
member.summary: Use this to get the whole XML body in one long string. Repeated uses should allow you to perform stepwise refinements, until you get to the innermost tag.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_COMPLETE_BODY
member.summary: Match the whole body of any HTML document. Except in special cases, you must employ the String and IgnoreCase modifiers to get this expression to work.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_COMPLETE_HEAD
member.summary: Match the entire Head section of any HTML document. Except in special cases, you must employ the String and IgnoreCase modifiers to get this expression to work.

member.summary: Match the entirety of any HTML document. Use this expression to discard preceding HTTP headers. Except in special cases, you must employ the String and IgnoreCase modifiers to get this expression to work.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_OPENING_TAG_ANY
member.summary:
Match any opening HTML or XML tag.
Except in special cases, you should employ the IgnoreCase modifier.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_CLOSING_TAG_ANY
member.summary:
Match any closing HTML or XML tag.
Except in special cases, you should employ the IgnoreCase modifier.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_COMPLETE_TAG_ARBITRARY
member.summary:
Match an arbitrary HTML or XML tag that appears on a single line (or multiple lines, if the String modifier is employed).
Except in special cases, you should employ the IgnoreCase modifier.
You must interpolate the tag name into this string by calling the the static string.Format method, passing this string as the format and the tag as the sole substitution value.
You may also pass a tag name to static method MatchArbitraryHtmlTag, which returns a pattern. For example, to find all Anchor tags, pass "A" to MatchArbitraryHtmlTag.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_OPENING_TAG_ARBITRARY
member.summary:
Match an arbitrary opening HTML or XML tag.
Except in special cases, you should employ the IgnoreCase modifier.
You must interpolate the tag name into this string by calling the the static string.Format method, passing this string as the format and the tag as the sole substitution value.
You may also pass a tag name to method MatchArbitraryHtmlOpeningTag, which returns a pattern. For example, to find all Anchor tags, pass "A" to MatchArbitraryHtmlOpeningTag.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.SGML_CLOSING_TAG_ARBITRARY
member.summary:
Match an arbitrary closing HTML or XML tag.
Except in special cases, you should employ the IgnoreCase modifier.
You must interpolate the tag name into this string by calling the the static string.Format method, passing this string as the format and the tag as the sole substitution value.
You may also pass a tag name to method MatchArbitraryHtmlClosingTag, which returns a pattern. For example, to find all Anchor tags, pass "A" to MatchArbitraryHtmlClosingTag.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.RegExpSupport.ExtractTextBetweenMatches(System.Text.RegularExpressions.MatchCollection,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Given the System.Text.RegularExpression.Match at index in System.Text.RegularExpression.MatchCollection , return the substring that follows the matching text in string up to the beginning of the next match, or the rest of the string inthe case of the last match.
member.param: Pass in a reference to the System.Text.RegularExpression.MatchCollection attached to a System.Text.RegularExpression.Regex that has one or more matches.

Pass in an integer that represents the index of the Match in for which to return the text that follows the text that matched it. This integer must be greater than or equal to zero and less than the Count property on MatchCollection .

Pass in a reference to the string that was fed into the constructor. This value cnnot be NULL or the empty string. It is the caller's responsiblity to pass in the same string that was passed into the constructor that created the because this function makes no efrort to use Reflection to test it.
member.returns:
There are two possible return values:
When is the index of the the last Match in , the return value is a substring comprising the text that begins immediately after the last character of the Value of the Match at index in the collection and continues to the end of string .
In all other cases, the return value is a substring comprising the text that begins immediately after the last character of the Value of the Match at index in the collection and continues up to the character at the position that corresponds to the Index of the next Match in the collection.
member.remarks: This method was perfected independently in my RegExpLab project.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ReportHelpers.MaxStringLength``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0})
member.summary: Given an array of objects of any type, return the length of the longest string made from them. See Remarks.
member.typeparam: This is a generic method; its argument may be of any type. This method needs only its ToString method.
member.param:
This argument expects an array of objects, which may be of different kinds.
Since the generic List class has a constructor that takes an array, which it copies into the new list that it returns, you can use this method to process arrays by specifying a new List of the appropriate type for this argument. For additional information, please see the Remarks section.
member.returns: The return value is the length of the longest string made from the objects in the input array. Since it is intended for use with the PadRight method on a string, it is cast to int. See Remarks.
member.remarks:
The goal of this routine is to determine the maximum number of characters required to represent any of a collection of objects such as labels or members of an enumerated type. This method has at least three use cases.
1) Pad the strings to a uniform length, so that all of a set of labeled values aligns vertically.
2) Construct a key from several substrings, such that the substrings are of uniform length, and the keys can be grouped by any of the leading substrings, and ordered by the values of the last substring.
3) Construct a composite format string that reserves enough room for the widest item in the list, so that whatever follows it on a report line aligns vertically.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ReportHelpers.CountCharacterOccurrences(System.String,System.Char)

summary.para: Strangely, the String class is missing an important static method to count occurrences of a specified character within a string. This is that missing method.

This method, which originated in StringExtensions, moves here as a private method because this class needs it and the extension methods class from which it cames must remain where it is to minimize the number of breaking changes.

member.param:
Specify the string in which to count occurrences of substring pstrToCount.
If pstrSource is null or empty, the method returns zero.
Since this is an extension method, pstrIn is supplied by the BCL when it binds this method to an instance of System.string.
Specify the substring to count in string pstrSource. An empty string causes the method to return MagicNumbers.STRING_INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND, or -1.
member.returns: The return value is the number of times, if any, that string pstrToCount occurs in string pstrSource, or MagicNumbers.STRING_INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND (-1) if pstrToCount is either null reference or empty the empty string.
member.remarks:
This method implements the only overload of the string.IndexOf method that takes a character as its second argument for which I have yet to make use. There is currently no implementation of the overload that stops looking after scanning count characters, nor do I have immediate plans to implement one, though it wouldn't be hard.
This method uses the same algorithm as CountSubstrings, except that its second argument is a single character, which CANNOT be the NULL character.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ReportHelpers.CreateLastToken(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: The last token is appended without a field delimiter. See Remarks.
member.param: The token used for the preceding operations is fed into this routine to have its delimiter removed. See Remarks.
Obviously, this routine needs a copy of the delimiter character, but its use is a bit more complex. See Remarks.
member.returns: Regardless of whether the delimiter is a TAB, which requires special handling, or another character, the return value is a bare token. See Remarks.
member.remarks:
Since they are escaped when entered into a .NET resource (.RESX) file, such TAB characters must be handled a tad differently, using the doubly escaped token that represents a TAB character embedded in a resource string as the first argument to the Replace method on the input string, pstrTokenTemplate. To cover the case where the string is a constant, embedded in the source file, this case must call the Replace method on the new string returned by the first Replace call, passing a string representation of the regular TAB character, since the replacement is the empty string.
In all other cases, the Replace method is called once, using the actual delimiter character, pchrFieldSeparator.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem
member.summary: Instances of this class represent arbitrary managed resource items.
member.remarks: This class is necessary because the public dictionary is opaque, so a consumer has no control over the order in which they are returned. Since this wrapper implements the IComparable interface, collections of these objects can be sorted.

Set the Value to the System.object returned by the Value property of the enumerator.

member.summary: The Name is the Name shown in the property sheet grid into which garden variety managed string resources are input.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem.Value
member.summary: The ResourceValue property is the Value property shown in the property sheet grid into which garden variety managed string resources are input, and its type is usually System.string.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem.TypeName
member.summary: Since the full type specification is accessible through the Value property, and the string representation of the FullName is its most useful property, it gets its own read only property, which also returns just "string" for the common case, for which the prefix is redundant.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem.System#IComparable{WizardWrx#SortableManagedResourceItem}#CompareTo(WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem)
member.summary: Making the comparison based on the Name property permits sorting the resources in the most logical order.
member.param: The explicit implementation puts the burden of enforcing type safety on the runtime system.
member.returns: Since it is a pass-through of another CompareTo method, the return type is guaranteed to adhere to the interface specification.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem.GetInternalResourceName(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Use the list of Manifest Resource Names returned by method GetManifestResourceNames on a specified assembly. Each of several methods employs a different mechanism to identify the assembly of interest.
member.param: Specify the name of the file from which the embedded resource was created. Typically, this will be the local name of the file in the source code tree.
Pass a reference to the Assembly that is supposed to contain the desired resource.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the internal name of the requested resource, which is fed to GetManifestResourceStream on the same assembly, which returns a read-only Stream backed by the embedded resource. If the specified resource is not found, it returns null.
member.remarks: Since I cannot imagine any use for this method beyond its infrastructure role in this class, I marked it private.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.SortableManagedResourceItem.ListResourcesInAssemblyByName(System.Reflection.Assembly,System.IO.StreamWriter)
member.summary: Call this static method from a console program to list the resources defined in an assembly alphabetically by name.
member.param: Specify the assembly that contains the resources to be enumerated.
Pass in a reference to an open StreamWriter to generate a tab-delimited report in addition to the console output. File output is suppressed when this parameter is null.
member.remarks: This method creates and consumes a generic List of instances of the class that hosts it, and uses string padding to vertically align the list without resorting to composite format items.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.SpecialStrings.ERRMSG_SUCCESS_PLACEHOLDER
member.summary: Since ErrorExit is never invoked for ERROR_SUCCESS, and the table of error messages is indexed by status code, this string holds its spot in the table of error messages, but is never rendered. Hence, it can be kept out of the managed string resources for applications. This string is publicly accessible through a static method exported by this library, ExceptionLogger.GetSpecifiedReservedErrorMessage.
member.remarks:
A related managed string resource, ERRMSG_SUCCESS, is available for public consumption; use it in lieu of this string for I18N.
Two other strings, ERRMSG_RUNTIME and ERRMSG_INVALID_COMMAND_LINE, are also defined in this assembly.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.SpecialStrings.SQL_DATETIME_FORMAT_PRECISE
member.summary: This string is the most precise string representation of the format of a SQL Server date.
member.remarks: Since date literals must be enclosed in single quotation marks, the formatted date value must be embedded in a string literal by interpolation or by way of a format item token. Regardless, the single quotes must be part of the string because including them in the format string invalidates it, causing ToString and its friends to render the format string as prescribed, rather than replacing it with the date value.

member.summary: If the count of objects to which a noun refers is greater than 1, replace its singular form with its plural form. Use this method to generate grammatically correct sentences in which the noun's number is grammatically correct.
member.param: Base the adjustment on this number.
Specify the noun to adjust, which is assumed to be in its singular form, and that its plural is the same word with the letter "S" appended.
Replace all instances of pstrNoun in this string with the plural of pstrNoun if pintNumber is greater than 1.

Specify the plural form of pstrSingularForm, either outright or as a plus sign followed immediately by the suffix to append.
If this arguments is a null reference or the empty string, the hard coded default suffix, a lower case s, is appended.
member.returns: The return value is pstrPhrase, amended if needed to reflect the correct number for pstrNoun.

member.summary: Strangely, the String class is missing an important static method to count substrings within a string. This is the missing method.
member.param:
String in which to count occurrences of substring pstrToCount.
If pstrSource is null or empty, the method returns zero.
Substring to count in string pstrSource. An empty string causes the method to return MagicNumbers.STRING_INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND, or -1.
member.returns: Number of times, if any, that string pstrToCount occurs in string pstrSource, or MagicNumbers.STRING_INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND (-1) if pstrToCount is either null or empty.

Substring to count in string pstrSource. An empty string causes the method to return MagicNumbers.STRING_INDEXOF_NOT_FOUND, or -1.

member.summary: Extract the substring bounded by the characters at either end of it.
member.param: Extract the substring from this string.
This integer is the position, given by IndexOf, of the character that bounds the left end of the desired substring.
This integer is the position, given by IndexOf, of the character that bounds the right end of the desired substring.
member.returns: The returned substring begins with the character immediately to the right of the left hand bounding character, and ending with the last character before the right hand bounding character.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.ExtractBetweenIndexOfs(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Extract the substring bounded by the characters at either end of it.
member.param: Extract the substring from this string.

This overload handles the case where the left boundary is bounded by a string. The method needs a copy of the string in order to find the true beginning of the substring to extract, and to compute its length.
This integer is the position, given by IndexOf, of the character that bounds the left end of the desired substring.
This integer is the position, given by IndexOf, of the character that bounds the right end of the desired substring.
member.returns:
The returned substring begins with the character immediately to the right of the left hand bounding character, and ending with the last character before the right hand bounding character.
Inputs and computed values are thoroughly sanity checked to prevent run-time exceptions. If anything is out of order, an empty string is returned.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.ExtractBoundedSubstrings(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Extract a substring that is bounded by a character. See Remarks.
member.param: The substring is extracted from this string.
This is the bounding character. Please see Remarks.
member.returns: This is the desired substring, without its bounding characters. See Remarks.
member.remarks:
The left and right ends must be bounded by the same character. To extract a string bounded on each end by a different character, use the next overload.
Inputs and computed values are thoroughly sanity checked to prevent run-time exceptions. If anything is out of order, an empty string is returned.

member.returns: This is the desired substring, without its bounding characters. See Remarks.

The left and right ends are expected to be bounded by different characters. To extract a string bounded on each end by the same character, use the previous overload.

member.remarks:

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.LengthOfLongestString(System.String[])
member.summary: Given an array of strings, return the length of the longest string.
member.param: The list of strings to evaluate is supplied as an array of strings, which may be an anonymous array, constructed on the fly in the argument list.
member.returns: The return value is the length of the longest string. If the array is empty or is composed entirely of empty strings, the return value is zero. Since it begins with a null reference test, this routine is always successful.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.MakeToken(System.String)
member.summary: Given a string containing the name of a form control (field) or other token, create its place holder token.
member.param: String containing the name of the token.
member.returns: String containing the text of the corresponding template text place holder. See Remarks.
member.remarks:
The string is constructed by appending a standard token delimiter, which is a pair of dollar signs, to each end of the string.
The token is exposed as a static property, DEFAULT_TOKEN_DELM.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.MakeToken(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Given a string containing the name of a form control (field) or other token, and another string containing a static token, create its place holder token.
member.param: String containing the name of the token.
member.returns: The string is constructed by appending the token delimiter specified in argument pstrTokenEnds to both ends of the string specified in argument pstrFieldName.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.ParseCommentInHTMLComment(System.String)
member.summary: Extract parameters, expressed as key-value pairs, from a standard HTML comment.
member.param: String containing a well formed HTML comment, surrounding the key-value pairs. If the string is not a well formed HTML comment, with a single space between the comment delimiters and the body, or the string is null or empty, the returned collection is empty.
member.returns: A NameValueCollection of parameter names and values, which may be empty, but is guaranteed to be returned, empty or not.

example.code:
Parse this: <!-- ForPage=default;UseTable=False -->
Return this:
======================= Name Value ----------- ----------- ForPage default UseTable False =======================
example.para: The returned NameValueCollection contains two members.
Since this method guarantees to return an initialized NameValueCollection, the empty collection is allocated by the first statement, and is unconditionally returned by the last statement.

If pintCount is less than 1, the return value is a null reference.

member.summary: Supply the missing Truncate function to members of the String class.

String to truncate, if it is longer than pintMaxLength.

Desired maximum length of the returned string. If pstrSource is longer than pintMaxLength characters, the first pintMaxLength are returned. Otherwise, the whole string is returned.
If pintMaxLength is less than or equal to zero, an empty string is returned.

Regardless, the return value is a new System.String object.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.StringTricks.TruncateValueToOneLine(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: The name says it pretty well; truncate the string representation of so that it contains only the first line of text.
member.param: Pass in the object for which a string representation is required.

param.name: pintMaxLengthOfOneLine
param.para: When specified, this optional value is the maximun number of characters to display.
This limit applies to all string represenntations, regardless of whether they contain embedded newline characters that already cause them to be truncated.

member.returns: The return value is a string that occupies no more than one line.
